div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: THE AUSTRIAN TRAVEL AND INFORMATION BUREAU.
div.p: (Under the Direction of the I. R. AUSTRIAN RAILWAY MINISTRY.) 86. PICCADILLY. LONDON, W.
The most delightful and health-giving resorts for Anglo-Egyptian Officials are the Alpine districts of Austria, which can be reached in a few hours from Trieste.
Excellent Hotels (to suit every pocket) abound situated in high latitudes of great recuperative power specially recommended by doctors for those who have spent a con-siderable time in a hot climate.
Various high Anglo-Egyptian Officials have already engaged villas, rooms at hotels, etc., for the ensuing vacation season.
Shootings and Fishings (at very low prices) can be arranged through the Bureau, also Castles and Villas can be let or sold.
The fullest information as to cost of tours, travelling and on every point will be sent by the Bureau on receipt of request.

div.head: The Nile
div.p: Sir William H. Preece’s paper, read before the Society of Arts on the 1st inst, in which he discusses the measures that ought to be taken to increase the flow and improve the navigation of the Nile between Assouan and Cairo, merits the careful attention of our Irrigation Department. This branch of the Egyptian Administration has hitherto been looked upon as the most efficient that the country possesses. What has it to say to the following impeachment extracted from Sir William Preece’s lecture? “I have seen no evidence whatever of any engineering operations in hand either to maintain the depth or to train the currents so as to keep the channels in their proper course.I havenot seen a dredger at work, but my line of inspection has been confined to Upper Egypt. On the other hand, the des­truction of the banks by the shadoufs is only too apparent. There are no charts of the river, nor is there any systematic survey in hand. I doubt if any other river in the world is so badly treated.” Further on the lecturer proceeds to point out that “thirty thousand tons of valuable mud are lost in the sea every year, and the rise of the bed of the river in the Delta is a very serious question.” It would be interesting to learn what the Department has to say to Sir William Preece’s strictures, and how far it is considered that the improvements he ad­vocates can be profitably undertaken. Surely so serious an indictment as the wanton neglect of Egypt’s single waterway and sole source of fertilisation, or, to adopt Sir William’s words, “the main artery of life and commerce of the country,” calls insistently tor some reply ; and the public mind, greatly disturbed by criticisms coming from so highly qualified an expert, will not be tranquillised without some official reassurance that matters are not so black as they are painted.

div.head: STATE OF RUSSIA.
div.p: GRAND DUKE'S MURDER
THE TSAR'S GRIEF
STRIKES EXTENDING

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The Tsar deplores in a manifesto the death, by the wicked hand of assassins, of his Uncle and friend “whose whole life was devoted to the service of ourselves and the Fatherland.” An extraordinary sitting of the Council of the Empire took place to-day in order to con-sider the situation resulting from the assas-sination of the Grand Duke Sergius. The leading Russian papers, while de-nouncing the assassination of the Grand Duke Sergius, declare that the need for reforms is largely responsible, as it promotes the revolu¬tionary propaganda. The town is being flooded with revolutionary literature (Reuter)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The Council of the Empire held an extra-ordinary sittirg on the occasion of the death of the Grand Duke Sergius. A manifesto of the Tsar expresses his grief at the assassination of the Grand Duke, whose every action had been devoted to the service of his country. Every Russian would share in the mourning, and would pray for the deceased. (Havas.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. The alarm caused here by the murder of the Grand Duke Sergius has been intensified by the scattering broadcast of violent revolutionary proclamations. Fresh strike troubles are announced from different parts of Russia. (Reuter.)
LONDON, February 19. The King has ordered Court mourning during a week for the Grand Duke Sergius. (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The strike here is again rapidly extending. 30,000 men have rejoined the strikers, whose temper is now more threatening than during the previous period. The troops have been re-drafted into the vicinity of the works. The police are renewing their domiciliary visits and arresting the leaders. (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The employees of the South Western Moscow-Riazan, Moscow-Kieff-Voroness and Mos- cow-Rybinsk-Windau railways have struck. The traffic on the last line is completely sus¬pended, and the others partially so. (Reuter)

div.head: THE WAR
div.p: RUSSIAN RIVERSE
RUSSIANS SURROUNDED BY JAPS

ST. PETERSBURG, February l8. A Russian correspondent at the front reports that a detachment with two guns, which was pursuing certain Japanese railway cutters on the 13th inst, was surrounded on the 14th by an overwhelming force of Japanese. The Russians suffered heavily and lust one gun. (R.)

St. Petersburg, February 18. A confused despatch from General Kuropatkin confirms the surrounding of a detach¬ment, mentioned this morning. It does not record any loss of any guns but mentions that in the attempt in save them the Japanese were pursued for 20 versts. (Reuter.)
MYSTERIOUS PEACE RUMOURS. ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. Mysterious rumours of peace, which are untraceable from any direct source, have been cropping up during the past few days. (R.)
RUSSIAN PAPERS SUSPENDED, ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. The papers “Nashi Dni" and “Nashi Shizn,” having been warned lor the third time, have been suspended for three months. (Reuter.)
GENERAL STOESSEL. CONSTANTINOPLE, February 19. General Stoessel has arrived here. (Reuter)

RUSSIAN REFORM. ST. Petersburg, February 19. The Committee of Ministers, after deliberating on the ukase of the 25th December, has drawn up some municipal improvements, which have been Sanctioned by the Tsar. M. Kedrine, the lawyer, has been banished to Siberia. (Havas.)

U. S. A. AND CHINA. WASHINGTON, February 19. The Chinese Minister has presented Mr. Roosevelt with a portrait of the Dowager Empress in recognition of America s part in the preservation of Chinese neutrality, and of the country s disinterested friendship. Mr. Roosevelt, replying, emphasized the strong interest of each country in the well-being and advancement of the oilier. (Reuter)

GREEK AUTONOMY. LONDON, February 18. Great Britain, France, Italy, and Russia have presented to Germany and Austria a note practically replying to the memorandum of the 22nd November. It says that the protecting Powers will not tolerate annexation without the consent of the inhabitants, but the wording generally appears to defer the realisation of the Greek hopes indefinitely. The Powers are willing, however, to withdraw their troops. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The S.S. “Antwerp City,” on board of which a fire occurred last week, left Alexandria for her destination yesterday.
M. Raoul Pugno’s Pianoforte Recital will takeplace at the New Khedtvial Hotel to­morrow evening, at 9.15 o’clock.
House-Show.—Owing to delay in transmis- sion through the post we are unable to publish our report of the Horse Show held in Cairo ou
Saturday.
Fire.—A fire broke out in the shoonah belonging to the Ottoman Bank at Alexandria at 8.30 o’clock oil Saturday evening. 42 bales of cotton were scorched. The damage is esti­mated at £250.

Germania Lodge.—The charity ball given by the Germania Lodge of Freemasons oil Sa­turday night at Monferrato’s Hal, proved a great success, from 250 to 300 dancers being present. The greatest animation characterised the function, which, we hope, will be the fore­runner of many more of the kind. As our readers are aware, the proceeds of the ball are to be devoted to the purchase of warm cloth­ing for necessitous children of all nationalities.

The Partial Eclipse ol the Moon which took place last nignt was Very clearly visible in this city, the evening being a fine one, and the atmosphere remarkably clear. The moon rose at 5.40, the first contact with the penumbra took place at 6.41 and withthe shadow at 7.54, the middle ot me eclipse was at 9 o' clock exactly, the last contact with the shadow at 10.7 and with the penumbra at 11.19. The magnitude of the eclipse was 0.41 of the moon's diameter, whereas in me partial eclipse of August 15 next it will only be 0.292.

Phenomenal Weather. — As our daily weather reports from Kom el-Nadoura observatory show, the weather at Alexandria for some time past has been quite phenomenal. On Saturday last, at 8 a.m., we touched the nearest point registered to zero since 1888. Atthat hour the thermometer was only 3 degrees Centigrade above zero. The minimum during the 24 hours at Asslout was 1 and Helouan and Ghizen 4 on that dale. Bad weather has been experienced in the mediterranean. The Florio-Rubatino S.S. "Singapore," which was due at Alexandria yesterday at 2 p.m, only arrived this morning at 6 o' clock.
The ALEXANDRIA MURDER.-- The two men

who, as we announced on Saturday, have been arrested on the charge of murdering the woman whose corpse was found in the Mahmoudiyah Canal some weeks ago, have been handed over to the Parquet and the enquiry is still proceeding. The trunk was found in a box in the canal and the head, arms, and legs were discovered close by. The police, when the discovery was made, were aware thatan old woman, about 60 years of age, who used to sell eggs in the Souk el-Cantar, had been missing for some days past. Itwas known that she wore artificial teeth, and when the head of the victim was discovered, the verification of this peculiarity established the identity. Some persons had seen two men wheeling a box by the canal, and the description of the box called(CANT READ) with that which contained the trunk. The murdered woman lived in the Souk el-Berslu(CANT READ), and one of their neighbours recognised the murderers from the description. They both live in the same house as did the victim, and when arrested accused each other of the crime. They are very pour and had been out of work for some time. The woman was evidently murdered for her valuables, as it was known that she had some jewelry and trinkets in her room.

div.head: Waiter Henry Hicks, deceased
div.p: PURSUANT to Act of Parliament 22 and 23 Vict., Cap. 35, Notice is hereby given that all persons having any claims against the Estate of Walter Henry Hicks, late of Cairo (who died on the 14th day of December, 1904, at Cairo, intestate, and to whose Estate Letters of Administration were granted on this day by the above Court to Mrs. Mary Hicks, the widow and relict of the said deceased) are required to send particulars of their claims to the undersigned, on or before the 31st day of March, 1905, alter which date the said Administratrix will proceed to distribute the assets of the said deceased amongst the persons entitled thereto, having regard only to those claims of which she shall then have notice ; and she will not be. liable for any assets so distributed to any person of whose claim she shall not then have bad notice.
Dated this 18th day of February, 1905.
For the Administratrix,
Em. Sciortino,
25455-1 Advocate, Cairo.

p.note:
SERIOUS ACCIDENT AVERTED.
T.R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, with the Princesses and H.H. the Khedive, honored the Cairo Horse Show with their presence on Saturday afternoon. Yesterday morning, their Royal Highnesses attended divine service at All Saints’ Church, and in the afternoon they drove out to Ghezireh. On their return across the Nile bridge, what might have been a nasty accident was narrowly averted. The horse of one of the soldiers of the escort was frightened by the noise made by the large motor belonging to Ghezireh Palace, which was drawn up with a number of other vehicles to allow their Royal Highnesses to pass the bridge, and plunged and fell with its rider. A policeman, named Papayanni, rushed up and by great prompti­tude succeeded in getting horse and rider up again just in front of the Royal carriage.
This morning the Duke of Conuaught in­spected the troops at Kasrel-Nil at 9.40 o’clock in the barrack square.
On Wednesday next the Duke and Du­chess will lunch at the Citadel alter the inspection of the troops stationed there.
On Thursday their Royal Highnesses will proceed to Bedmchein before lunch in the steamboat “Misr” and will remain till the evening at Sakkarah.
On or about the 27th inst. their Royal Highnesses, who will probably be accompanied by Sir Wm. Garstin, G.C.M.G., will visit the Cairo Barrage.
The date of their arrival in Alexandria is still uncertain, but it is probable that they will come down in the afternoon of the 27th and leave on March 2 by H. M. S. “Essex” for Cyprus.
Owing to Court mourning for the late Grand Duke Sergius, their Royal Highnesses will be unable to attend any social functions.
MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
A telegram from Mecca states that the Egyptian pilgrimage has arrived at Mecca, the health of the pilgrims being perfect.
The Board of Health at Constantinople has declared the pilgrimage as free from epidemic.
FITZNER QUATUOR.
The second Fitzner Quatuor concert took place at the Khedivial on Friday before a small but appreciative audience. The charity perform­ance next door at the Zizinia Theatre doubtless would account to a certain extent for the absence of some who would otherwise have been present. But the concert-going public of our city require to be spooned with tickets and only buy when pressed to do so. Anyhow, amateur performances are better attended than those of the best European artists. The programme was a very beautiful and highly interesting one and opened with a Quatuor in D Major by a Russian composer, Giazounow. The Andante Allegro led off with a fugue motif followed by a melody which was taken up by each instrument in turn and again replaced by the fugue motif. The Allegretto was noticeable for its pizzicato passages and cadenzas in thirds perfectly played and apparently the performance of one instrument. The Adagio was incomparably the finest movement of the quartet. It seemed an imitation of the weird music of the AEolian harp, and one distinctly heard the storm fined angrily dashing against the strings and the gentle sighing answers of zephyrs wearied out by the unequal contest. The Allegro was a bright finale of feathered songsters twittering gaily after the cessation of the storm. Dvorak’s Lento, entitled ‘Dumky,’ a Czech word, which was untranslatable even to Austrians present, appeared to resemble a Scotch or an Irish lament in its plaintive wailing melody, so much so that we feel sure a Dumky is the expression musically of forlorn love or a desolate hearth. It elicited a hearty encore which brought hack the performers, who played an Andante movement from one of Grief’s quartets, which was played in a masterly way and brought to a finish with an astonishing chord passage of harmonics. Cherubini’s Scherzo, which followed, was a sportive lively number, and then came the “piece de resistance,” Beethoven’s Quartet in E Minor (op. 59 No 2). How can we dare describe the breadth and beauty of this music al giant’s compositions? We cannot do better than refer music-lovers to Sir George’s Grove’s Essay on Beethoven’s instrumental music. Although the hour was late, nearing midnight, the audience was still enthusiastic, and another encore was granted, when a second movement from Grieg’s Quartet was given, a picturesque martial number in which the dash of arms and the sorrowful tunes of mothers and wives wailing for their lost ones followed one another in quick crashing chords and softened subdued passages of impassioned grief. The finish and ensemble of the Fitzuer Quatuor was admirable, so we have confined ourselves to a mere description of the beautiful music they played. It was altogether a feast for music-lovers.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK
div.p: MEETING OF SHAREHOLDERS

The annual general meeting of shareholders in the Agricultural Bank of Egypt takes place to-day. The directors have to report that the net profits of the bank for the financial year 1904 amount to £157,859.9.11. Deducting, for the service of the bonds outstanding, the provision for the reserve fund, the dividend on £625,000 preference shares, and 5 % to the National Bank of Egypt,a total of £86,684.11.1 is available for the distribution of the dividend on Ordinary and Deferred shares. The directors propose a dividend at the rate of 6 per cent. per annum for the year 1904 on the Ordinary shares, amounting to £74,400. They also propose a dividend at the rate of £6.3.0 for each Deferred share, amounting to £21,300. At the end of the year 1904, the overdue loans for the year amounted to £21,220, and the over-due interest to £7,209. Of these amounts £713,730 and £4,530 have been collected respectively since the closing of the accounts for 1904.

The constantly increasing applications for loans make an extension of the powers of the bank for providing capital necessary, and accordingly negotiations have been entered into with the Government, the result of which will be communicated to the shareholders in due course.

div.head: SAVOY SMALL DANCE.
div.p: Last Saturday’s small dance was the best witnessed this season, and perhaps in any previous season. The restaurant, ball room, hall, etc., were all too small to contain the large gathering. During dinner especially the aspect was very striking. The Duke and Duchess of Connaught and suite had dinner in the restaurant. The Royal party arrived about 8.15 and seemed very interested in the dance. The Duke sat in the hall after dinner and chatted freely with several of the Savoy visitors.

Among others we noticed in the restaurant were Mr. and Mrs. Livingston, with 8 guests, including Baron von Oppenheim, Count Kodzicbrodzki, Mr. C. Palmer, Misses Anderson, Mr. and Mrs. Ochs entertained Sir John and Lady Rogers and Sir Gerald FitzGerald. Mr. Suares had as guests Baron and Baronne de Menasce. Mr. and Mrs. Nugent, Harari Pasha and Mme Harari were entertained by Mr. and Mrs. Heidelbach. Mr. and Mme Michel Tueni had a party of 9, Mrs. Rodger Lovell and Miss Price a party of 6, the Misses Hurley a >arty of 5, Major E. Herbert a party of 6. Mr. and Mrs. Coats and party entertained Gen. Sir Stanley Clarke and Capt. Stanley Clarke. There were over 150 extra dinners in the restaurant and as many suppers after the lance.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: On Saturday evening was successfully produced. this perhaps least popular of Meyer­beer’s works. The opera, however, contains many opportunities tor the artiste playing the title role, and these were fully taken advantage of by Signora Isabella Svicher, who was rewarded by enthusiastic applause and numerous handsome baskets of flowers. This accomplished artiste also proved herself a clever ’cellist and after the first act of the opera charmed her hearers with a skillful rendering of a delightful composition by Offenbach, played with exquisite expression and technique, and accompanied by the orchestra. Signora Svieher was ably supported by Signor Borrione and Montanari in the respective roles of Hoel and Corentino. The invisible choruses were exceedingly well rendered, and proved quite a feature of the performance. The opera was well staged and the orchestra, as usual, excellent.

To-night Massenet’s “Manon” will be staged, with Signora Bellincioni in the title role, and from the crowded audiences who attend this lady’s performances it is hardly necessary to state that those who wish to be present should book their seats as early as possible.

div.head: MR. ALDERSON'S RESIGNATION
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE ‘‘EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”

Sir,—We, the undersigned, the President and members of the Committee of the Tenants’ Commission of Alexandria, having read the letter of Mr. Geo. B. Alderson in the “Egyptian Gazette” of Saturday, 18th inst., do hereby declare that that gentleman's letter is based on totally erroneous suppositions. In the first place, the statutes of the Societa Anonima delle Case Economiche have not been submitted to the Egyptian Government, as we fully explained to Mr. Alderson in his private office on the 14th inst. The allegations of Mr. Alderson on this point are therefore totally incorrect. The only reason for Mr. Alderson's resignation was that he wished to control the entire scheme without any assistance from other capitalists. He wanted 10% interest on the capital, as he had stated to the Municipal Commission, but we refused to entertain this proposal. We may add that we approached the local capitalists with the consent of Mr. Alderson.—We are, etc.,
L. Ronci, president; S. J. Agius, G. Calebotta. A. Maravalli. F. Quintavalli G, Menasse, A. Spada, G. M. Perrakis, J. Angelo, members of the committee.
Alexandria, February 18.

div.p: We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The ex-Empress Eugenie left Luxor on Thursday afternoon on her way up the river to Assouan.
During the stay of the Duke and’Duchess of Connaught at Luxor last week they paid a visit to the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, who happened to be at Luxor on their dahabieh.

H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus, of Swe¬den and Norway, and suite, including Baron Ralamb, chamberlain, and Capt. Swerre, aide- de-camp to H.R.H., have arrived in Cairo, back from their Nile journey, and are staying at Sbepheard’s Hotel.
H.H. the Maharajah of Khapurtala, with a large suite, is expected in Cairo early in March and will stay at the Ghezireh Palace, where several apartments have been reserved for him.
Lord and Lady Cromer are expected to return to Cairo from their Nile trip on Wednesday.

A dinner was given at the Savoy Hotel yesterday evening by Comte Thadde Bolesta Koziebrodski, Diplomatic Agent for Austria- Hungary, in honor of Boutros Pasha Ghali. The guests included Ahmed Mazloum Pasha, Minister of Finance, Abani Pasha, Minister of War, M. and Mme Maskens, Marquis and Marchioness Salvago-Raggi, Dr. and Mme. Rucker-Jenisch, Gen., Mrs. and Miss Slade, De Martino Pasha and Mme De Martino, Comtesse de Fugger-Babenhausen and daughter, Mrs. Campbell, Miss Hurley, Miss Gertrude Hurley, Mr, Vincent Corbet, Sir William Garstin, Izzet Pasha, Gen. Thurneyssen Pasha, Negbib Bey Ghali, and Comte Stadnicki.
Fabricius Pasha is giving a big dinner party at the Savoy on Wednesday, and Hon. J. W. Riddle is giving one on Thursday.
Earl Howe will remain in Egypt with Lady Howe until late next month, when they return to Gopsall for the Easter holidays.
Mrs. Carton de Wiart has been very unwell, aud has kept her bed for the last week. Her engagements have been cancelled until March 1.

The restaurant of the Grand Continental Hotel presented an usual aspect on Friday night, when, after the performance of The Pirates of Penzance, the entire troupe assembled in costume at the supper given in honour of the occasion by the committee of management. The arrangements, in the hands of Mr. Nungovich, left nothing to be desired. A sumptuous repast was followed by speeches and the drinking of numerous toasts, and the company separated at a late hour.

The death is announced, as having taken place at Newport, Mon., of Mrs. A. E. Garwood, wife of a former engineer-in-chief of the Locomotive, Carriage, and Wagon Depart¬ment of the Egyptian State Railways.
Mrs. Peacock and family beg to express their heartfelt thanks to the many friends who have shown sympathy and kindness in their sad bereavement

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: AVIS

Meesiaurs les Actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoques en Assemblee Generale Ordinaire pour le Lundi vingt Mars 1905, a trois heures at demie da l’apres-midi, au Siege Social(INKBLOT), an Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR:
Rapport du Conseil d’Administration.
Rapport des Censeurs.
Approbation es Comptes de l'exercice clos le 31 Decembre 1904.
Fixation du dividende.
Renouvellment partial du Conseil d’Adminiatration.
Election des Censeurs pour 1’exercice 1905.
Fixation da l'indemnite des Censeurs.

Tout actionnaire possedant au moins vingt actions a droit do prendre part a l'Assemblee Generale a condition do deposer ses actions dans l'un das lieux ci-apres desigues ou il lui, sera delivre une carte d’admission.
En Egypte: Cinq jonrs au moins avant le jour de la reunion, soit le 15 Man au plus tard :

au Siege Social, au Caire, a la Succursale d'Alexandrie, aux Agences de la Banque a Assiout, Assouan, Benha, Beni Souef, Chibin-El-Kom, Damanhour, Fayum, Keneb, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Sohag, Tantah, Zagaeig et Musky (Caire).
a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank,
a la Banque Imper. Ott.,
au Credit Lyonnais,
a la bank of Egypt.

En Europe, au plus tard le 10 mars: a Paris et a Marseille, aux bureaux de la "Societe Marseillaise", en Italie dans les bureaux de la "Banca Commerciale Italiana”, a Londres, a l'Agence da la National Bank of Egypt, 4 at 5 King William Street.
Le Gouverneur :
Elwin Palmer.
Le Caire, le 18 Fevrier 1905. 25456-10-*1

div.head: Société Anoyme du Béhéra
div.p: AVIS

Messieurs les Actionnaires de la Société Anonyme du Bébéra sont convoqués en Asseblée Générale Ordinaire le Mardi 14 Mars 1905 à 3 heures 1/2 de relevée au Siège de la Société, 6, Bue Adib, pour délibérer sur l’ordre du jour suivant :
(1) Audition du rapport du Conseil d’Administration sur les Affaires de la Société.
(2) Audition du rapport du Censeur.
(S) Approbation des Comptes de l’exercice 1904 et fixation du dividende.
(4) Nomination d’un censeur pour l’exercice 1905.
Et à l'issue de cette séance les actionnaires sont convoqués eu assemblée générale extraordinaire pour délibérer sur l’ordre du jour suivant :

(1) Proposition a) d'augmenter le capital de U société par la création de 100,000 actions privilégiées de £ 5 chacune, amortissables par tirage au sort au gré de la société et selon ses disponibilités et donnant droit k un intérêt annuel et cumulatif de 5 %.

(b) de répartir actuellement 50,000 de ces actions privilégiées jonissance ler Janvier 1905 à raison d'une action privilégiée pour chaque action ordinaire, en représentation des bénéfices acquis sur les reventes des terres de la Société.
(2) Modifications des articles 5, 7 et 38 des statuts comme suit :
ARTICLE 5 (1er paragraphe)
TEXTE ACTUEL
Le fonds social est fixé à la somme de L.E. 250,000 divisée en 50,000 Actions de L.E. 5 chacune
TEXTE PROPOSÉ

Le fonds social est fixé à la somme de L.E. 737.500 représenté par lo) 50.000 actions ordinaires de LE. 5 chacune. 2o) 100.000 actions privilégiées Amortissables de £ 5 chacune qui seront successivement remises entièrement libérées, aux porteurs des actions ordinaires au prorata du j nombre d'actions possédées par eux et en vertu de délibération de l'assemblée générale des actionnaires en représentation de bénéfices acquis sur les reventes des terres de la société.
ARTICLE 7 (1er paragraphe)
TEXTE ACTUEL
Chaque action donne droit dans la propriété do l’actif social et dans le partage du bénéfice à une part proportionnelle au nombre des actions émises.
TEXTE PROPOSÉ

Chaque action ordinaire donne droit dans la propriété de l'actif social et dans le partage des bénéfices à une part proportionnelle au nombre d’actions émises . Les actions privilégiées n’ont droit qu’à un intérêt de 5% l’an cumulatif et an remboursement an pair et à titre privilégié de leur valeur nominale par voie d’amortissement en vertu du tirage au sort.
ARTICLE 38 (1er paragraphe)
TEXTE ACTUEL

Sur les bénéfices nets de l'exercice social après déduction de tous frais et charges de la société, il sera prélevé d'abord la somme nécessaire pour fournir un intérêt de 5 % sur le capital nominal des actions.
TEXTE PROPOSÉ

Sur les bénéfices nets de l’exercice social après déduction de tous frais et charges de la société il sera prélevé d’abord la somme né cessa ire pour fournir le 5 % d’intérêt prévu à l’article 7 des statuts au nombre d’actions privilégiées, dont l’assemblée générale aura autorisé la distribution proportionnelle aux actionnaires.
Ensuite il sera pré levé la somme nécessaire pour fournir un intérêt do 5 % sur le capital nominal des actions ordinaires.
Pour le surplus le texte actuel des trois articles précités est maintenu.

Tout porteur de vingt actions a droit d’as sister à l'Assemblée Générale, mais conformé ment à l’Article 24 de» Statuts, il devra justifier auprès de la Société du dépôt de ses Actions un jour avant la date fixée pour la réunion. Il est rappelé qu'aux termes de l'article 30 des statuts il no pourra être délibéré valablement sur les objets portés à l'ordre du jour de l’assemblée générale extraordinaire qu'au tant que les actions représentées formeront au moins la moitié du capital.
L'Administrateur-Di recteur,
(Signé) E W. P. Poster,
Alexandrie, le 16 février 1905. 25447-4*-l

div.head: BOURSE KHEDIVIALE
div.p: Remarques sur le marché du disponible et des contrats.
Samedi, le 18 février 1905.
Cotons

Disponible.—Il y a eu une assez bonne demande pour le spot, surtout pour les bonnes qualités, mais devant l'exagération des prétentions des vendeurs, les affaires out fini par se ralentir. Les prix pourtant restent très fermes et la hausse de la semaine varie de 1/4 à 8/4 de talari, suivant genre et qualité.
Franco-Station.—On n'y fait rien.

Contrats.—La nouvelle récolte a été constamment ferme, mais oe matin elle a attiré tout particulièrement les faveurs de la corbeille. La tendance est excellente et la spéculation ne peut que s'y intéresser davantage de jour en jour.

La vieille récolte est celle naturellement, dont on s'occupe le plus et, comme conséquence, l'activité y a été très grande. Bu effet, les transactions y ont été suivies et nombreuses et comme résumé, elle a avancé de près d’au talari depuis samedi dernier. Le découvert qui existe encore et le revirement quasi général dans l'opinion quant à l'avenir de l'article font penser que nous verrons de plus hauts cours, spécialement si le mouvement sur l'Américain continue.
Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour mars tal. 13 3/16 à —/—; plus bas pour mars 13 1/4 à —/—.
Graines de coton
La demande pour lo disponible a été modérée, mais, avec l'amélioration de Hull et la fermeté des contrats, les cours ont nécessairement gagné du terrain sur samedi dernier.
Franco-Station.—Nullité complète.
Contrats.—Nouvelle récolte. Ne donne lieu qu'à de rares affaires, oe qui ne l'empéche pas de se soutenir. Les vendeurs hésitent à se découvrir aux prix actuels.
Vieille récolte.—Elle a subi quelques fluctuations ; au fond, cependant, elle est peu animée, quoique fermement tenue.
Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour le février-mars P.T. 55 1/4 à —/— : plus bas pour le février mars 54 3/4 à —/—.
Feues
Disponible et franco-gare, nullité oomplète.
Bn contrats, les acheteurs manquent sur la nouvelle récolte, tandis que la vieille récolte est bien tenue par quelques gros intéressés.

div.head: THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE
div.p: SPECIAL NOTICE

Gilbert and Sullivan's delightful comic opera, “The Pirates of Penzance," was performed at the Khedivial Opera House in Cairo on the 17th instant. From a financial standpoint the enterprise proved a triumphant success ; the receipts amounted to over £700, a sum which exceeded the takings for any single performance since the theatre was built. The price of £50 was paid for one stall alone, and many of the boxes were sold at a premium of £20 or £30. The house was filled from floor to ceiling and presented a gala appearance. His Highness the Khedive was represented. Their Royal High­nesses the Duke and Duchess of Counaught, with the Princesses Margaret aud Victoria Patricia, arrived punctually at nine o'clock ; they occupied the Khedivial box aud remained until the end of the performance. Major-General and Mrs. Slade were present ; in the boxes we also noticed Lady Willcocks, Mme Fabricius Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Perry, Mr. and Mrs. Alban, Dr. Murisou, Mr. and Mrs. Archi­bald, Mr. and Mrs Thobron, Mr. and Mrs. du Boulay, Mr. aud Mrs. Scott-Dalgieish, Mrs. Milton, Mr. aud Mrs. Poster, Judge Willmore, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall, Mme Suare, Mr. Vin­cent Corbet, Mr. Mitchell Innes, Mr. aud Mrs. Rowlatt, Catiaui Bey, Mr. and Mrs, Cookson, Mr. and Mrs. Morice Bey, Mme Allred de Meuasce, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, etc. Other box- holders were Me. Carton de Wiart, Mr. Morgan, Sir Elwin Palmer, H. E. Izzet Pasha and Prince Mohamed Aly. In the stalls were Mrs. Coles Pasha and her daughters, Mrs. aud Miss Boyle, Sir Horace Pinching, M. Sinadino, Mr. and Mrs. Kingstord, Judge and Mrs. Tuck, Mr. and Mrs. Gunn, Dr. Saudwith, and a host of

A special feature in the evening's entertainment was the lecer de rideau arranged by the courtesy of the Société Artistque. The Khedivial opera company assembled on the stage, which was tastefully decorated with flags and flowers, and sang "God save the King” in magnificent style. They were accompanied by the private band of the Khedive (conducted by Mr. C. Franklin) and by the orchestra. The graceful tribute was highly appreciated by an essentially British audience. A selection from the opera Sesotris (of which Mr. Franklin is the composer) was given as an entr'acte.

The opera scored a fresh success in the annals of Cairo amateur theatricals of which the established standard of excellence is decidedly above the average of amateur performances. The piece was well rehearsed and well put on, and went with scarcely a bitch from start to finish. Principal and chorus alike worked unremittingly, the latter with an animation that conduced greatly to the brisk action throughout. The ladies presented a bevy of beauty, and on their entry formed a very charming group. A lusty chorus of pirates opened the 1st act and brought it to a spirited conclusion. In the 2nd act the policemen's chorus held the stage; their business was most amusing ; in their fight with the pirates the play of truncheon versus cutlass was quite realistic. The entrance of the ladies — General Stanley's daughters — in white peignoires and carrying lanterns, had a pretty effect. This started the finale, which worked up well and made a good ending to a thoroughly admirable performance.

Among the principals, Mr. S. H. Trimen, as Major-General Stanley, gave a clever rendering of the part assigned to him; he is a finished actor aud an excellent comedian. We have seen the part in other most capable hands, and it is according no small meed of praise to say that Mr. Trimen worthily upheld the traditions attaching thereto. His topical song, 'I am the very model of a modern Major- General,' was well received, his encore verse provoking general laughter. Captain the Hon. C. James, E. A. played the Pirate King to perfection. His costume of red and black, profusely ornamented with skulls and crossbones, gave him an appropriately ferocious appearance. His pleasant voice—a particularly sympathetic baritone—was heard to advantage in his song, 'I am a Pirate King,' and in the trio 'A Paradox.’ His acting throughout was most spirited and telling. An agreeable tenor voice and a keen sense of humour enabled Mr. F.S. Webb to sustain the difficult and somewhat thankless role of Frederick with success; his singing was hampered by a severe cold but in spite of this his solo, ‘Oh, is there not one maiden here?' (one of the most graceful, airs in the opera), and his duets with Mabel and Ruth were very satisfactorily rendered. Captain A. N. Tucker, R.E., was inimitable as the Sergeant of Police. His fine voice was well suited to his numbers, "When the foeman
